description:
Visit exciting attractions, meet cherished characters, eat snacks, collect souvenirs, and experience magical moments throughout Magic Kingdom Park in Disney Happiest Day Game. Along the way, you'll share your favorite ways to spend the day. When Tinker Bell reaches the top of the castle, the game board magically transforms from day to night!

—description from the publisher

Something Wild! Star Wars: Boba Fett is a fast-paced, light card game. Play numbered and colored character cards to make sets and runs, just like in Rummy. Power cards specific to the included character add a fun twist to the classic card gameplay. The first player to score three powers wins.

You can combine multiple Something Wild! games to add more character cards, more Pop! figures, and more powers to a game.

The King wants to stop the many love letters arriving in the castle. So he arranged for prospective suitors to temporarily come and meet all the ladies to earn their trust. The suitor with the most support from the ladies is permanently allowed inside the castle.

Love Letter to Lady Luck (LLLL) is the sequel to the widely acclaimed game, Love Letter. As it shares the same background world setting, the art and layout is the same as "Love Letter". However, it plays differently from the original.

You bid on cards which you either use as collaborator or score cards. The collaborator cards help you gain better cards or manipulate your own or your opponents' decks. But score cards help you win the game.

You can also play Goita with the same cards.

Released as part of Princess Wonder.  It was not released in a separate retail edition.

A top speed, high energy,  family-friendly card game that’s perfect for parties.

Don’t keep your customers waiting; serve the food they ordered as fast as you can!

In this fast & frantic card game, play table cards, then fill their orders by playing food cards onto them. The catch? Everyone can play on anyone's cards, and everyone plays at once!

Serve the most tables and play the most cards overall to score big points and get the "tip jar" bonus!

—description from the designer

In Sleeping Queens 2: The Rescue!, the Pancake Queen, the Ladybug Queen, and their friends return with some new characters and a new mission: Save the kings!

Play queens to rescue kings from a parade of perilous predicaments. Find a magical companion to aid your quest, but watch out for Wild Gnomes, Sleeping Willows, and the ever-sneaky Switch Witch! Each player has a knight in front of themselves with a special power, but don't get too attached because if anyone rolls a dragon on the die, all the knights move left. Save the most kings and crown yourself the royal hero!

—description from the publisher

Each player in Chonky Donkey has a hand of question cards. In a round, the active player draws a card from the answer deck and reads it out loud. Each other player in turn chooses a question card from their hand and reads it, after which the active player must give their answer without laughing. If the active player succeeds in keeping a straight face, they keep their answer card as a point; otherwise they give it to the person whose question made them break. Play until someone collects the required number of points to win.

Floppies? Beepers? Emojis? Memes? The generational divide is alive and well. See how well you know the generation you love to mock. From tech to tunes to terminology, Millennials and Boomers go head to head in this LOL, pop culture trivia game.

Not a boomer or millennial? Not to worry, this is a game every generation can play.

Perfect for trivia night, family game night...or any night.

The best chefs are in the town.
But the best cannot be many!
Cooking competition was held to determine the superiority!
In addition to cooking skills, you need "a little bit" of luck to win.

Gather ingredients!
Use cooking tools!
Treat guests!
Be the best chef!

There're 5 cooking ingredients. Meat, Fish, Vegetable, Wheat, Rice. You can get these ingredients with cards or dice. Draw an 1 card or roll 2 dice. The cards belong to the individual, and the dice belong to everyone. Therefore, only roll the dice when you are sure!

If someone makes 5 dishes, game ends. The player with the most points wins.

In The Emissary, you are a young noble sent by your father to gather support from eight neighboring kingdoms. In each kingdom, you engage in a series of debates with their ruler. Using the right amount of force and deference, you must win exactly a certain number of debates per kingdom. Succeed and you may call upon the ruler for future support; fail even once and lose the game.

The Emissary is a solo trick-taking game playable with a deck of regular playing cards, with rules created by Wil Su and made available free online as part of his "Isaludo" series. The game begins by arranging the deck's eight kings and queens in a row. The player then "visits" each card, in whatever order they choose, drawing a new hand of eight cards from the remainder of deck at each stop. They then draw cards one at a time from the deck, forming the basis of tricks, which the player answers from their own hand. The catch is that whatever place the king or queen being "visited" by the player is (e.g., 1st place through 8th place), that's how many tricks must be won by the player -- no more, and no less. With only a limited capacity to bend the rules through special abilities, the game becomes an exercise in careful hand manipulation and excruciating trade-offs.

The game is inspired by the decktet game Gongor Whist, which itself was patterned from the standard-deck card game Oneonta Whist. This game also holds the core for the free print-and-play game For Northwood!, which swept top prizes in the 2021 BGG 54-card contest. Familiarity with trick-taking games will make understanding the following rules a breeze. Of course, prior knowledge isn't strictly necessary.

In Skyway, you are a city planner in charge of designing a notoriously convoluted traffic interchange. Over three passes through the deck, you will be drafting stacks of cards from a random market, which you’ll place into a 3x3 grid. However, each grid cell may only be stacked three cards high - any more and the bottom cards get discarded. Your aim is to create a path of at least 5 increasing cards for each of the four suits.

Skyway is a solo pattern-building game playable with a deck of regular playing cards, with rules created by Wil Su and made available free online as part of his "Isaludo" series. On each turn, the player deals stacks of cards to a market, and then chooses one stack to build inside a 3x3 grid. Over three passes through the deck, the player tries to construct the grid in such a way as to create a five-card sequence in each suit -- a pathway formed by the cards that can snake around or intersect with the other suits' pathways. The catch is that each square on the grid can only hold a stack of cards three high, and placing the one card needed to complete one pathway may very well cause a card crucial to another pathway to be discarded.

Arranging tiles to create maps is a cornerstone of many great city-building games like Suburbia and Sprawlopolis. However, most games of this genre require more information on each card than a simple rank-and-suit system can provide. Skyway takes its cue from the Decktet game Aucteraden. By allowing a single space to have more than one “suit” on it, the paths can intersect and weave around each other to create a small, tight puzzle.

As part of the Isaludo collection, the rules can be found in this forum thread.

The once-great Iron Kingdoms are now a pile of smoldering ruins, and there's treasure everywhere if you've got the gumption to fight for it! You'll need a crackerjack crew, gobs of gear, and lots of love for the chaos of battle if you're going to score the best leftover loot in the land — but it's every human, dwarf, elf, and goblin for themselves in this outrageous quest for bodacious booty!

Riot Quest is a fast-moving, highly unpredictable skirmish board game using hobby miniatures. First released in 2019 using hobby miniatures, Riot Quest has enjoyed three years of expansion and growth. The new board game edition will include 48 preassembled plastic miniatures and all the dice and accessories needed to play the game with up to four players.

The Deathbusters have captured someone from the Sailor Guardians team and replaced them with a Daimon imposter! By asking the team members questions and seeing whose answers don't align with the rest of the group, the team can unmask the imposter and direct the rescue of their captured teammate before it's too late.

In Sailor Moon Crystal: Imposterous, players take turns asking intriguing and open-ended questions related to the Sailor Moon Crystal series. Each player writes down an answer that they think will match the answer given by other players. The more answers a player has in common with the others, the more points they receive. The suspicious player with the fewest points each round, i.e., the one whose answers are most dissimilar from those of other players, might be the imposter and their pawn moves down the game board.

When a player — or multiple players! — exit the last space (Level 6) of the game board, the game ends with the imposter(s) having been revealed. All the remaining players win the game and rescue their captured teammate!

Can you get the bunny trio to the Golden Ei inn before the fox catches up to them?

In Golden Ei, you win or lose together. To set up, shuffle the 28 double-sided trail cards, flipping half the deck repeatedly to randomize which sides are face up, then lay out the cards in a trail with the Golden Ei inn card at one end and the Fox at the other. Place the bunnies 8-10 spaces away from the fox depending on how difficult you want the game to be, with each bunny on their own card.

To start, roll the die, then move the matching colored bunny (blue, red, yellow) forward one space. Next, choose the closest vacant trail card either in front of or behind the bunny just moved, then flip it. If the card shows 1-2 eggs in yellow, red, or blue, move the matching bunny forward 1-2 spaces, then once again flip over the closest vacant trail card either in front of or behind the bunny just moved. If you instead reveal 1-3 fox paws, move the fox forward 1-3 spaces, then pass the die to the next player, who rolls the die to start a new turn.

If the fox lands on a bunny, you lose, but if any bunny first lands on the inn, then they all reach safety!

Golden Ei includes six helper cards, such as a dice squirrel and a taxi stork, that you can add to the game. You start only 6-8 spaces away from the fox, but each helper animal provides a one-time benefit that will ideally keep you out of the fox's jaws.

This is an adventure game, where the heroes are wandering around the Kingdom and facing challenges. They receive victory points for solving problems and dealing with monsters. Every completed challenge releases a memory piece from the Mine of Memories and helps the heroes to restore the forgotten Kingdom. The revealed memories reduce the difficulty of further challenges and earn extra victory points for the heroes.

The heroes’ task to get all the memories back from the mine and assemble the forgotten cities on the board to break the evil spell. Players do this by moving up to 3 spaces on the hexagon grid during their turn and either resolving tile events by playing their cards or placing their Memory Tiles to gain points.  The player who has the most points at the end of the game is the ruler of the Kingdom and wins the crown.

The Western Legends Big Box is more than just a box, its also a complete wooden storage solution that holds every single item (except the playmat) from the Game: Western Legends series. Contents vary with version purchased.

The Alllll In version includes all upgraded components, the hardcover rulebook, and stores all game boards as well! It also comes with unique never before seen character cards and a legendary item!

The New In Town version has a softcover rulebook and does not include playmat and some of the component upgrades.

Chopping Block is a fast paced card game for junior- and mid-level executioners where you need to outbid your unscrupulous coworkers for the juiciest contracts in town. If you're lucky you'll even have time for a cup of your favorite hot beverage.
Probably coffee. Definitely coffee.

The game is a card game for 2-5 players with bidding mechanics and cut-throat player interaction to gain the most gold. You gain gold and influence by fulfilling contracts for executions of various nobles (and other unfortunates….). You can spend both Gold and Influence during the game to get benefits or sabotage your executioner colleagues' work.  The player with the most gold at the end of the game wins.

You Win is a massive multiplayer card game for larger parties, events, and conventions. Players start with an equal number of You Win cards each (at least 1) and face off in quick 1 vs 1 games. The winner, determined by a couple of card flips, will take up to as many cards as they played from their opponent (while keeping any cards they played). The player with the most cards at the end of the event wins the whole game. But players don't know how many cards are in the pool, how many cards other players have, or how many cards to play against each opponent.

The game can be played in-hand, in less than a minute, while standing or waiting. It's an ideal ice breaker game with player choice, luck, and exciting tie breakers. All the rules are on the card.

You Win is a massive multiplayer card game and is distributed as a Forever Free Print and Play Game for personal use.

Solitaire Legends is a series of traditional-style solitaire card games based on popular myths and legends.

Tiger Lily is a solitaire game based on Peter Pan that can be played with a traditional deck of cards. The game was created by Jonathan Auffarth in 2022.

Long gone are the days of Captain Hook and the boy who wouldn’t grow up. Now, pirates battle for control over Neverland, and the Fairy Kingdom is enslaved. Their pixie dust is harvested as a weapon of war. Alas, a new hero rises. All aboard the Jolly Roger as Queen Tiger Lily leads the Lost Boys to free the fairies once and for all!

In Tiger Lily, you must take control of the Jolly Roger. To do so, Find and align 3 Lost Boys (J) in a vertical, horizontal, OR diagonal line. On your turn, play a card from your hand, resolve the action, and then draw back up to 4. Catch Fairies along the way, fight Pirates, and look out for the Crocodile lurking in the water below!

For more games in the Solitaire Legends series check out Guinevere and Maid Marian!

Roll'N'Wrestle is a modern day twist on the 1950-1980 Wrestling era with you taking the role of a pro wrestling promoter.

The United States of America is divided into territories and you must conquer these by hosting wrestling events and attracting fans to your promotion.

Lead your wrestling franchise to success and beat the competition by recruiting, training, and developing a winning roster of wrestling superstars.

You will roll dice acting as your road agents to complete worker placement strategic maneuvers for your promotion, plus deal with superstar egos, backstage rivalries and locker room politics, negotiate deals with TV networks and sell merchandise to your hopefully increasing loyal fan base! Plus so much more...

Do you have what it takes to beat ruthless rival promotions 
and conquer the world of Professional Wrestling?

Come and try in Roll'N'Wrestle: Territories the pro wrestling board game.

SayÅ« is an abstract strategy tile-laying, tile-flipping for two players. It is played with 49 unique two-sided octagonal wooden tiles and uses no board. The objective of the game is to have more tile of your color face up when all the tiles are placed.

To setup the game place the home tile at the center of the table. This tile has no arrows. From now on no tiles can be placed further than 3 spaces away from this tile (this creates a 7 by 7 grid when finished).

Players then take alternate turns. On your turn you must choose a tile that is still available and place it on an empty space - up, down, left or right of a tile already placed.

You must place it in any of the 8 possible orientations you wish. The orientation of a tile is indicated by the white arrow in the middle.

Once a tile is placed, check whether it can convert an opponent's tile over to your side - to do so you must fulfill three conditions;

1) your tile must have your color arrow pointing toward your opponent's tile
2) the target opponent tile must not have their color arrow pointing back
3) the two tiles must not share the same orientation

If multiple tiles can be converted at the same time you may only choose one.

The converted tile is flipped over to your side and rotated to the same orientation as one that converted it. You then treat that tile as though it just been placed and check if another conversion can be made. Repeat this process until no further conversion is possible.

Now it is your opponent's turn.

Players will take turn placing and converting tiles back and forth in this manner until all the tiles are placed and the game is over. Count up the total number of tiles for each player; whoever has the most of their color facing up is the winner.

A Deadbolt Mystery Society mini mystery.

Nicolas Polk was a gifted artist. Even as a student enrolled in Valley Falls University’s prestigious art program, his work always stood head and shoulders above the rest. Fittingly enough, Nicolas was announced as the winner of the annual LaBelle Art Show. Imagine everyone's surprise, however, when the young savant was found dead the next morning inside the art gallery. Can you catch the killer before they get away with a picture-perfect crime?

As with all Deadbolt Mystery Society games, you step into the role of the detective. Examining the evidence provided,visiting different locations and using the password protected QR mechanic to uncover the truth.

Players win once they catch the killer, find whats missing or whatever else is needed to solve the case at hand.

—description from the publisher

Tech Chess is a two-player, chess variant game where chess pieces each have abilities. It replaces the pieces with a modernized deck of playing cards called the Tech Deck. The cards represent chess pieces on the board each with special abilities. Played on a 6x6 board, each player starts with two kings, a knight, queen, two rooks and 6 pawns that can be upgraded. Players draw 3 cards from the deck at the start of the game. If you like chess, you'll enjoy Tech Chess.

On their turn, a player may do one of the following things, Move a piece, Use card effects, Upgrade a piece, Build a pawn.

Pronouce Txek as "check", a reference to our origins: Basque Country across France and Spain.

This is a card game where each player has cards they can - and can't see.  The goal of the game is to be the first to discard all your cards by matching the cards on the discard pile.  But other players can use special cards to stop you along the way.

Similar game play to UNO but you can't see all your hand at once.

Pluzzables are “playable puzzles” - a collection of puzzles you play as games after assembly. Additionally, two web apps come with the game for simpler "match and claim" games. You do not have to put the puzzle together exactly in order to play Destinations. However, to play the online Pair Up game, all the pieces must be in their correct positions.

The Destinations edition is a puzzle of vintage travel posters. After assembly, the puzzle becomes a board game where players fly airplanes to various locations to collect lost luggage.

Players are given tickets that contain not only destinations, but a variety of actions that can influence movement of airplanes. On their turn, players roll dice, use a ticket, and either move, collect suitcases, or perform an action.

Once all luggage has been collected, the player with the most luggage points is the winner.

Baker's Dozen, America's most beloved baking competition show, is in trouble! One of the five remaining contestants is planning to poison one of the judges tonight during the live taping of the show's semi-final. The icing on the cake? If you alert the contestants that you suspect foul play, the killer will have a chance to escape.

Difficulty 1/5 (Easy)

—description from the publisher

Dungeon Doodle is a two-player roll & write game in which one player takes on the role of Dungeon Lord to design a dungeon behind his player screen, while the other player plays the Hero trying to conquer it.

As Dungeon Lord, roll your dice to draw your Dungeon. Place Traps, Doors, Treasures and Monsters. Protect your Crystals. If you snatch all of your opponent’s Health Points, you’ll win immediately. At the end you will earn Victory Points by protecting your crystals, treasures, and Health Points you have earned from the Hero.

As the Hero, roll your dice to assault your opponent’s dungeon.
Move, fight Monsters, find Keys, and Treasures. If you find your opponent’s 3 Crystals you’ll win immediately. At the end you’ll earn Victory Points for stealing treasures, defeating monsters, conquering Crystals and the Life Points you keep.

—description from the designer

The A New Hope Limited set was the first full expansion set of the Star Wars Customizable Card Game. It consisted of 162 cards dividing into 81 Dark Side and 81 Light Side, and was introduced in July of 1996. This set consisted of 54 rare, 54 uncommon, and 54 common cards. This set introduced many of the classic characters from Star Wars: Episode IV A New Hope, that were not included in the original base set, Premiere Limited. This set also introduced the first epic event cards, such as Commence Primary Ignition and Attack Run, to the game.

Important debuts in this set included Chewbacca and R2-D2. Also of note were the introduction of the Death Star as a system card, the introduction of creatures, and a new mechanic that allowed for the destruction of entire planets.

A classic board game playing pantomime or answering trivia questions on Greek and International Cinema. In a round metal box (cinematic bobbin), 2 packages of 100 photos, original dashboard, wooden pawns and dice.

The board has a similar use as with trivia games, there is no start and end, but it's purpose is to stop over different frames (places) to be asked different questions about the movie between: "title" by doing pantomime or verbally by looking at the picture, "director", and "actors/actresses". For that, a pawn and a dice are used giving you the option to select the type of questions that you are most familiar with. One side of the card is showing a scene from the movie, while the other has the title, director and actors/actresses involved.

When a movie card is played, the player/team has to answer the question to win it. If he/she/they can't reply then the next player has the opportunity to do so, etc. A movie card never returns to the pile.

The goal is to collect as many movie cards as possible throughout the game. The game ends if all the cards from the deck are finished of when the predefined time has passed. The player with the most cards on hand is the winner.

You're on the hunt for One-Eyed Willy's fabled treasure with the Fratellis close behind in this immersive cooperative family strategy game! Maneuver your way through the tunnels and around challenges like the Bone Piano to discover the "Rich Stuff" at the end of the journey but only if you can stay ahead of the Fratellis! Bring back your best childhood memories and watch your kids fall in love with this classic adventure movie.

The Goonies Game is here to bring you into the thrilling world of the Fratellis, the Bone Piano, the Goon Docks, and more. Work together to discover the rich stuff at the end of the journey! One-Eyed Willy has his hands on the treasure you are searching for. Solve the challenges with the silver doubloon and the copper bones key to unlock the secrets and find the treasure.

In this game, you work together with the other players to run away from the Fratellis and clear challenges (dice rolls and blind guessing) before they reach you. All 4 groups of Goonies are always in play so these will need to be divided over the number of players. Players play cards on their turn to move (mandatory) and can optionally try challenges (if they're on a challenge space), try to break free from the clutches of the Fratellis (die roll) and play a quote (a one time effect played, unique per card).

The Goonies need to reach the end of the board to win the game, they will also need to have at least 25 'rich stuff' which are found at the end of the board and mostly comes down to blindly taking the correct ones.

Sosaria has become overrun by evil creatures and the land is in turmoil.  The King has sent out an urgent request for the bravest adventurers to help purge this evil from his kingdom and save Sosaria.  Those who are brave enough to take up the challenge will be richly rewarded with land, titles and riches.  But for those who do decide to take up this gauntlet you must take heed for evil doesn’t just roam the land; it swims deep in the oceans and creeps deep underground within the three dungeons of Sosaria.

Victory Conditions: 
You win the game once you complete three quests given by the King of Sosaria to rid the land from the evil that has rising from the darkest dungeons.  You must search the land for three magical signposts.  Each signpost marks the spot of a magical gem that holds a secret message.  There are three signposts holding three gems: Blue, Green, and Red.  These magical gems “when deciphered by the King” will give you access to their dungeons.   The first quest will be to find the blue dungeon which will be guarded by Beholder.  The second quest will be to find the green dungeon which is surrounded by water and guarded by a Minotaur.  The last quest and the most difficult will be to find the red dungeon which is surrounded by mountains and guarded by a Balrog demon the most feared evil monster of all.  Find the three signposts in order of blue, green and red to recover each gem. Travel back to the King after each signpost to decipher the message in the gem.  The King will then tell you where to find the dungeons so you can defeat the monsters within to become the savior of Sosaria.
You lose the game if your health drops to zero or you fail to complete the three quests.

—description from the designer

Biomes is a board game where you will expand your lands and develop buildings to gain the most points by the end of the game.

The game

A game for 1-4 players, draft from the available tiles to lay and connect new biomes. Once you have created an area that can be developed, build buildings to gain resources, and gain points.

An extremely fun and rare board game, based on the famous TV series.  It was released in Greece during the 80's by Tjitji Toys. It can be played from 2-4 players. 
Before start, each player gets 30$ from the bank. Then, everyone in his turn, roll the 2 dices (the usual one and the colorfull one). When you roll the usual one, your move your pawn (General Lee) the exact number on the board.  Then you roll the colorfull one and you move the pawn with the police car.  The police car can be moved back and forth. When a player reaches a spot where stands another player,  he must pay him 5 dollars and stay in the previous spot.  When the police car hits another player,  the player who has been hitted,  must pay 5 dollars to the bank.  In case, that a player must pay the bank and he has no money, as a result he returns to the starting point. 
Furthermore, when a player reaches a spot with a question mark on it,  he must take a card and follow its rules. 
The winner is the player who reaches the finish line, with the exact number on the dice.

—user summary

Lifeline is a territorial strategy game for two players (Black and White) that is played on the cells of an initially empty hexhex board. The recommended board sizes are between 3 and 12 cells per side.

The game was invented by Michael Amundsen and Luis Bolaños Mures. Although inspired by Go, it bears a significant resemblance to Kanare Kato's Meridians.

				
				
					DefinitionsA group is an entire set of connected stones of the same color. A single stone, not connected to others of its color, is also a group.

A group is dead if there is no path of connected empty cells between that group and any other group of its color. The path does not need to be a straight line.

				
				
					PlayBlack plays first, then turns alternate. On your turn, perform the following actions in order:


     Place a stone of your color on an empty cell. If it is your first turn of the game, perform this action twice.
     Remove all dead enemy groups.
     Remove all dead friendly groups.


The board positions at the start and at the end of your turn must be different. In other words, if the only stone you remove is the one you just placed, your placement is illegal.

The last player to make a placement wins. Note that, after your first turn, you will always have a placement available unless you have no groups on the board.

To make the game fair, White will have the option, on their first turn only, to swap sides with Black instead of making a regular move.

				
				
					VariantsThe standard game is made fair by the combination of the double first move and White's swap option, as described above. This balancing method is called strong pie. Some alternatives are:


     Weak pie: Instead of placing twice on their first turn, players place one stone on every turn, and dead groups are not removed until there are at least four stones on the board. White's swap option still applies, but takes place after Black has placed only one stone.



     Komi pie: Before the game starts, the first player chooses a whole number as the komi value, and then the second player chooses sides. The first four stones are placed in the same manner as with weak pie, but there is no swap option after Black's fist placement. Throughout the game proper, White will have the option to spend a point of komi instead of making a placement.


Unlike strong pie, these methods require somewhat large boards to be effective: at least base 6 for weak pie, and at least base 7 for komi pie.

—description from the designers

In Airships and Automatons players play as an Automaton that can convert into an Airship and back again. They will be traveling around their city sheet completing tasks with dice rolls. Certain areas require the  player to be an Airship while other tasks require the player to be an Automaton. Further still, there are two spaces that can be used by either.

Players will have to move each turn, 1 space as an Automaton or up to 2 spaces as an Airship. They will use their dice to Convert, move an extra space or two, or activate their area of the City. Players also gain powers and create combos by completing tasks in the City.

Opportunities arise for players who are playing quickly to trigger a bonus by moving back into Area 1 of the City which allows all players to Convert, but the triggering player to earn a special bonus.

The game plays over 12 revolutions of the City sheet. Each revolution will last a number of rounds determined by the players. Will they play fast? Will they play slow to do all of the actions? The choices are plenty!

Scoring is done for each area with the players having a grand total at the end. The winning Automaton will have to master the clock as well as plan ahead each time focusing to maximize areas so they can outscore their rivals.

Airships and Automatons can be played solo or with up to 4 players. There are suggestions for how to combine the airships and automaton cards, but with this print and play format, players can create any number of combinations they choose. Additionally, printing out a set of cards for each player allows them to choose their own combinations and see if their own skill can beat their opponents when using the same Airship/Automaton combination!

Get ready to roll and write in this all new Steampunk game!

—description from the designer

ã‚»ãƒ¼ãƒŽ (Seeno) is a two player card game from Japan. Using the theme and gameplay of rock, scissors, paper, the game has three characters, ã‚°ãƒ¼ (GÅ«), ãƒãƒ§ã‚­ (Choki), ãƒ‘ãƒ¼ã§ (PÄ de). Each player gets six cards, numbered 1 to 3, which count as hits to win draws. These three battle it out but also have special abilities on action cards. A quick game that children and adults can pick up easily.
user summary

A fast-paced, competitive, space challenge for 2-4 players.

You are a Nova Raider, part prospector and part pirate, in this space age race for riches. Compete with other Raiders to collect the valuable energy crystals surrounding an unstable star. Grab as much as you can before the expanding star consumes everything in its path, including you.

Use your dice to  Hop between Teleports or fly around the Orbit Rings to collect Energy Crystals. Gather these crystals under your ship and try to bring them back to your Space Dock before somebody Hijacks your cargo.  The time track is constantly moving forward, triggering the addition of more energy and the dangerous expansion of the star. The expanding star consumes everything in its path, until it goes Super-Nova, ending the game. Whoever collects the most energy before the Star goes Super-Nova will win the game.

—description from the designer

Thorgal: The Board Game is a cooperative storybook adventure game. Players take on the roles of Thorgal, his wife Aaricia, their son Jolan, and Kriss —a deadly female warrior—, and go on a series of adventures. The game consists of 7 stand-alone scenarios, each taking roughly 90-120 minutes of play. Scenarios do not form a campaign nor have any legacy features, so they can be played by different playgroups and over an extended period of time.

Thorgal: The Board Game comes with a book of maps. Each scenario is played on a different map that players explore while fulfilling scenario goals and promises completely different adventures, hidden opportunities, side quests, and vivid characters. Players are free to choose whether they travel in one group or split to cover more areas at the same time. Each character gains experience during the game and advances their abilities. Characters gather resources and craft objects to help them survive in the dangerous world.

There is a storybook containing narrative descriptions of the encounters that Characters make in each scenario. The adventures described in the book are specific to each scenario and Character, with randomized elements offering higher replayability and allowing for repeated play. There are also Side Plots players can pursue to gain benefits and reveal additional pieces of the story.

Thorgal: The Board Game also has a unique action selection mechanism. In this new mechanism, actions have varying power depending on which other actions have already been taken. Players must carefully plan their strategy and sequence of actions taken, as this directly impacts the strength of the effect of each action.

—description from the publisher

The Gamefound edition has more content.

Klangraupe is a memo game. The matching pairs have the same name in German, but look completely different (homonyms).

Klangraupe ist ein Memo-Spiel. Passende Paare heissen gleich, sehen aber ganz unterschiedlich aus (Homonyme).

As an art agent in Bidding Room: Underground, you have been employed by powerful families to represent them in a secret underground bidding room for illegal artifacts. Your task is to spend their money wisely to get goods that are worth points. Additionally, you have secret tasks and privileges that will sway how you bid.

To set up, one player takes the role of auctioneer and deals each other player a face-down agent card that includes a breakdown of all 27 artifacts in the game, while listing that player's specific privileges, such as receiving extra money for winning certain types of auctions. The auctioneer records the starting funds for each player — $40-50M depending on the player count — and sets up the artifact deck by shuffling three gift cards with the 27 artifacts. Only 10-20 items will be sold during the game, with that number being determined by the player count.

For each auction, the auctioneer reveals the item, then conducts the auction specified by that item, such as an open auction in which players write bids on their personal boards and raise them, an auctioneer bid in which the auctioneer calls out amounts and players lower their hand to drop out, a sealed bid in which agents reveal their bids simultaneously, and a second price bid in which the winner pays only the amount of the second-highest bid. If the auctioneer reveals a gift card from the deck, this gift goes to the player who won the most recent bid.

The auctioneer tracks the funds that all players have available, and an agent must track their own holdings — and everyone else's — mentally. If they win a bid for more than they have, they must sell off previously acquired items at their listed opening bids to acquire funds.

Once the specified number of items have been sold, whoever has the most points wins.

Opportunity is the family fun game featuring real local businesses as its properties.  During the course of play you will buy, sell and expand businesses for profit, and face some of the same problems business owners and managers face on a daily basis.  Players should find Opportunity intriguing as they match their intuition, decision making skills and luck against that of their opponents.

—description from the box

We aren't fans of not knowing fact from fiction, but sometimes you have to laugh to keep from crying. And what better place for a much-needed laugh than game night with friends?
 So we’re taking an old favorite game — Two Truths and a Lie — and updating it for truly crazy times. Can’t tell the actual Trump quotes from ones that are completely made up? SAD. But hilarious! So Make Game Night Great Again!

—description from the designer

In turn, players are given a three statements from a card, read by the player on their right, and they must guess which one was not made by Donald Trump. If they guess correctly, they keep the question card; if they answer wrongly, the player who read out the statements keeps the card. After a set number of rounds, the game ends, and the player who has collected the most cards wins the game.

—user summary

Doodleface is a drawing game.....Potluck Style.

Instead of bringing your favorite food, bring you own interpertation of your friends facial features.

Every player gets a doodle pad and writing tool.  Shuffle the appropriate cards and "Try your best" to draw your friends well.  In future rounds themes get added for even more fun.

After all the faces are drawn, players vote on the best drawing.  Who ever was the one being drawn, wins.

Dikti is a fast, fun and reflexive game! Use the letters on the cards to create words that match the categories indicated and get rid of your deck before the others do! Multiple game variations guarantee hours of fun. It's a fast-paced game starring words.

The once thriving Roman Empire fell apart. Who can resist the temptation to claim some of the lands for themselves? Do you prefer vineyards or quarries? Or maybe you want a little bit of everything with some olive groves and an oil mill on top? All you need is to make a good trade: offer a beautiful antique theater in exchange or add a few precious diamonds… Divide and swap lands, outguess and bribe your opponents! Create a prosperous domain from the lots of Rome!

Rome in a day is a simple strategy game based on the original "cut-and-choose" mechanic that will win the hearts of aspiring conquerors of all ages.

Before the start, all players are dealt with their personal set of buildings with the card of buildings, a pile of lands tiles (there are 5 types - fields, city, olive gardens etc), gems/cristals, choice cards of smaller and bigger lands, reminder cards and screens.

The game is played in 4 turns.

During each turn, players take top 5 tiles of lands and place them in front of themselves. Then they take 2 top buildings from the building card and place them on the 2 lands from the left.

Next, players take their screens and start dividing those 5 pieces of lands into 2 groups - a bigger and a smaller ones. In any ratio they want (3\2, 1\4 even 5\0). And add 1 crystal to the smaller land.

When everyone is ready, the exchange begins.
Players put the screens down allowing other players to see and choose a land that they have made.

Note: at the first turn players choose the lands from a neighbour from the left, at 2nd - from the right, and then again left and finally right. For the max interaction

When selection is made, players put a choice card reflecting their decidion of lands.

Then, players take the chosen lands from the neighbour from the left and join them to the remaining piece of their own.

Turn by turn, they build their domains, taking the most suitable lands to make their so-called new empire more profitable.

How to gain points?
For every kind of terrain with the corresponding building placed on it or next to it. Then the number of lands multiply with the number of buildings for EACH type of lands.
The crystals gained for choosing smaller lands also bring points - 3 points for each crystal.

The player with the most points wins the game.

5 Seconds Junior Edition 2019 is a specially prepared edition of the iconic 5 seconds game with kids in mind! Surely you can easily name 3 flavors of jam - but can you do it under time pressure? Hurry up, you only have 5 seconds

Small escape room adventure directed to children. Your friend has disappeared, and it is rumoured that there is a ghost in your school.

A deck of 34 cards, including story and puzzles to solve along the way.

Ego Pictures is the next instalment of the social game EGO. Thanks to the pictures you will get to know each other better! There is no wrong answer here! The main attraction of the game are the pictures. Choose for yourself, which picture you like best and which you like least. Which picture best represents the drawn text? The task of the other participants is to guess your choice.

Do you think that the other participants know you well?

You will soon find out!

ãƒ–ãƒ¼ã‚±ã€œèŠ±æŸã‚’å›ã«ã€œ (Bouquet ~Bouquet for you~) is a card game from Japan. Players build up a hand of flower cards to form bouquets by getting cards into sets in the style of Rummy. Pairs, runs, flushes, various card combinations work to score. Players can exchange flower cards and use a butterfly piece on the cards to add to their score.
user summary

What do a cat and a star have in common? How about cotton and a rock? Puzzle Frenzy challenges players to find the common follow-up word that ties the clues together:

star fish . . . cat fish

With another clue -- Halloween -- for cotton and rock you might figure it out:

cotton candy . . . rock candy . . . Halloween candy

Try to discover the connections between seemingly unrelated words as you build jigsaw picture clues. The first team to solve the master picture puzzle wins.

—description from the publisher
